data.title: Thanks for the Memory (1938)
data.meta_description: Steve Merrick is an out of work writer who stays home and plays house husband while his wife goes to work for her former fiancé and Merrick's publisher who is still carrying a torch for her.
data.text:
George Archainbaud’s comedy in which the wife (Shirley Ross) of an out-of-work writer (Bob Hope) takes an occupation with her husband’s publisher, who turns out to be her previous fiancé.

Adapted from the stage play by Albert Hackett and Frances Goodrich, which occurred eight years before, the story concerns Steve (Bob Hope), a jobless writer who remains at home and is the house husband while his wife Anne (Shirley Ross) goes to work for her ex-fiancé (Otto Kruger) and Steve’s publisher who continues to secretly admire her.

Bob Hope and Shirley Ross both give good performances in their respective parts as Steve and Anne, the husband-and-wife involved, with Steve the unemployed author and Anne working for her previous fiancé.

Elsewhere,…

In this movie, has Bob Hope teamed with Shirley Ross with whom he sang the Oscar winning song by this title in his feature film debut, The Big Broadcast of 1938 which had been released the previous February. This November, 1938 release features Hope as a writer working on a novel but having a penchant for procrastinating and going out partying rather than focusing on his work. His wife, played by Ross, wants to get a job to help with finances, but her prideful husband husband is against it. She does so out of necessity and ends up working for her former fiancée, which cause another conflict. The Paramount brass wanted to team Hope and Ross in a film by…

Bob Hope and Shirley Ross reunite in this gentle romantic comedy which seems like little more than a build-up to them reprising their "Thanks For the Memory" vocal duet in "The Big Broadcast of 1938."

This time Hope is Steve Merrick, a struggling writer in New York City working on his first novel. Miss Ross plays his wife Anne, a model who stopped working when she married Steve to take care of house while he finishes his novel. They have lots of friends and acquaintances who pop in and out of their apartment and their lives, but none of them are quite as witty or funny as the script would like them to be. A lot of jokes about drinking…
